story.text: (Adds comments, details throughout, byline) By Jonathan StempelNEW YORK Jan 3 (Reuters) - A former Morgan Stanley (MS.N) regional director in wealth management sued the Wall Street investment bank on Wednesday, saying he was fired because of his age. Edward Sullivan, 56, who had been a managing director, accused human resources executives Jeffrey Brodsky and Eric Kayne of conspiring to end his employment, in part to make room for a friend of Brodsky's who lacked an assignment. Sullivan said the executives interfered with his 2005 annual review, even preparing a "made-up, poison-pen critique" of his work to advance their cause. The Darien, Connecticut, resident said their actions helped lead to his May 13, 2006 dismissal, 10 days before his 56th birthday. Brodsky "marked the aging Mr. Sullivan for termination," and enlisted Kayne's help, according to the complaint. "He (Brodsky) wanted Sullivan terminated even though there was no reason to terminate him, and he wanted it done now, before Sullivan got any older." Jim Wiggins, a Morgan Stanley spokesman, said: "The lawsuit has absolutely no merit, and we will contest it vigorously." He said Brodsky and Kayne still work for Morgan Stanley and were not available for comment. "Morgan Stanley holds itself out as subscribing to a culture of excellence and management transparency. Our client alleges that those promises were not honored," said John Crossman, a partner at Zukerman Gore & Brandeis LLP who represents Sullivan. "He was a 25-year veteran, well-respected, frequently commended, and all of that has been taken away." Sullivan sued Morgan Stanley and the executives in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. He is asking for his job back with seniority and benefits, and at least $30 million of compensatory and punitive damages. The plaintiff was one of six regional directors who lost that title last March when James Gorman, who runs Morgan Stanley's global wealth management unit, streamlined the business's management structure. Gorman halved the number of regional directors to four. He kept two of the existing directors and hired two others from Merrill Lynch & Co. MER.N, his former employer. Sullivan had worked for Morgan Stanley or its predecessors since 1981, according to the complaint. He rose to managing director in 1999 and was paid between $800,000 and $1 million annually from 2001 to 2005, the complaint said. Wall Street investment banks regularly face bias lawsuits. In 2004, Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $54 million to settle bias charges filed on behalf of hundreds of women who claimed they were denied raises and promotions and subjected to lewd behavior.
story.title: update 1 - morgan stanley sued by former exec for age bias
